nova/scheduler/manager.py.message:
ok that makes sense
thanks for recording it.

i dont know if we could eventully remove this by getting the instnaces current allcoation and mapping those in some way.

but for now this is enough.

in the future we could do the ordering of the alloction candiates in the weigher without needing to change this by the way.

i.e. order the list before it gets here.
yeah that would be a possibility too. Good point.

im not sure we would want to recondier an alternitive allocation candate on teh same host at this point.

its possible for numa reasons that that would be valid but i think we would want to prefer candiates form other host first in a sort of bareber poll striping algortiom

i.e. wehre we take the first candiate from all hsot then the second candiate for all hosts and so one 

if we only had one host that would still try up to n candiates but i think that would be better form a multi create perspective.

I agree we want to spread by host first to avoid races. 
There is a hidden complication here btw. For the main selection we already allocated the candidate in placement so that is fixed. BUT for the alternative selections all candidate is just a candidate. So the quest should we use a single candidate in more than on alternative for different VMs? In case of PCI and PF this would lead to unnecessary reschedules. But for VFs or non PCI VMs this might be totally fine. The core of the issue is that placement does not tell us how many times a candidate would fit to a given host based on the available resources. We only know that it fit at least once.

Hello James,

Thank you very much for the review!

The terminate_connection method has some special and undocumented behaviour, especially for the multi-attach case - please take a look at the Cinder manager source code:

kind: KubeletConfiguration

Above CSV string section if we find matching 'key' we delete the 'key=val' from the CSV string.

Here if we find matching 'key' and boolean matching 'val' we pop the 'key' from the dict and only delete from info it the resulting feature_gates is empty.

Please confirm:
This removes the key from info if resultant feature_gates not empty, since the feature_gates actually refers to the same location contained in info, so by modifying feature_gates we are modifying info.

i.e., feature_gates = info.get(section).get(featuregates_string) is actually referring within info, is not a copy of the result.

correct, if there is a 'featureGates' key under info.get(section), then info.get(section).get(featuregates_string) will return a dict that is still part of 'info'.

Since dicts are mutable we can then change it by popping the unwanted feature gate, and it will affect the contents of 'info'

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
As it's currently configured, /var (fluxdata) holds what was effectively is a mix of the CentOS root filesystem, / and /home.

The following is currently mapped into /var
root@localhost:~# ls -ald /* | grep var
lrwxrwxrwx   3 root root     8 Feb 27 05:25 /home -> var/home
lrwxrwxrwx   3 root root    18 Feb 27 05:25 /media -> var/rootdirs/media
lrwxrwxrwx   3 root root    16 Feb 27 05:25 /mnt -> var/rootdirs/mnt
lrwxrwxrwx   3 root root    16 Feb 27 05:25 /opt -> var/rootdirs/opt
lrwxrwxrwx   3 root root    17 Feb 27 05:25 /root -> var/rootdirs/root
lrwxrwxrwx   3 root root    16 Feb 27 05:25 /srv -> var/rootdirs/srv
drwxr-xr-x  14 root root  4096 Feb 27 00:40 /var

And the usage is 

Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sdc5        20G  614M   18G   9% /var

Post-install under CentOS we have approx 11G available for the end user:

Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda4        20G  7.6G   11G  42% /
 
After this change /var will be associated with /sysroot (otaroot) and have more available space than we did under CentOS.

Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda4        20G  4.7G   14G  26% /var

The idea of using the fluxdata partition for /var basically isolates /home/sysadmin (grows with user data) from the /sysroot partition which holds the ostree repo (grows with platform patching updates).

I'm ok with this change if the ostree repo size doesn't grow significantly with updates, but I'm concerned that if the sysadmin user loads a bunch of temporary files on the platform to enable k8s applications (docker images, tarballs, etc) this can consume a lot of space and this will compete with space required by the ostree repo.
Is this ready to merge? @Al @Bob ?

I think the ostree repo will grow signifigantly with updates.
I have seen the one in my build env grow from less than 2 to be over 10G after a dozen or so build-images over a few week period.
I did a quick grep of the code, and it looks like you got them all.  Makes sense to have this in the ssh_utils.
LGTM - thank you very much!
Looks good to me

deliverables/antelope/python-cinderclien.message: Minor (Y) version increases signal feature additions or changes in external dependencies, which aren't something I'd expect to see merged to a stable branch. When in the past was it needed?

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

deliverables/antelope/python-cinderclien.message:
That's interesting. I thought by policy we didn't change external dependency versions in stable constraints, even when they announced security vulnerabilities. Doing so is a very slippery slope and implies to users that we think installing the versions of dependencies in the stable constraints lists is production safe (it's definitely not, that's not at all what it's for and we have things in there with widely-known vulnerabilities which we intentionally ignore because we're trying to stick with contemporary versions of them which lack those fixes).

Anyway, it was pointed out in IRC that there was a case in the past where a stable branch policy violation was intentionally merged to os-brick and the maintainers wanted to be able to signal to consumers that they had done so. I suppose if this is going to be commonplace, we should change the policy to recommend major version increases after branching any library, since there's no way to predict whether or not they will actually follow policy over the course of the cycle. I'm sure that problem is not limited to the Cinder team's deliverables alone.

Zed was 9.1.0 and now we are proposing 9.2.0 for antelope.
The concern which I've faced in the past with this type of versioning is we've very less room for stable releases when we've bugfix backport and even for bugfixes we need to do the patch version bump Z in X.Y.Z and not minor bump because we are updating the minor version here and not the major version.

We've needed this in the past when an external library has a security fix, and we must update the requirements.txt to raise the min version, and sometimes, modify our code that consumes the library.  We've tried to use minor version bumps to signal that it's not just a patch release, but it's a serious change that operators should upgrade to.

Ack, I think using major versions would handle the case I've mentioned above and also allows us to easily track which tag is associated to which branch like
8 -> Yoga
9 -> Zed
10 -> Antelope

So I would prefer the major bump. thanks.
cycle-with-intermediary model requires only MINOR version bump between cycles, but I think we can accept if a team want a MAJOR bumnp instead.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Anton: BTW, do you have a way to easily reproduce this issue?

Hey, Anton. Thanks for sending this, but I think this was an ovs bug that should be fixed. In any case, we can't do sleeps in this part of the code or it'll also block things like handling echo requests or reconnecting to ovsdb-server if there's a problem.

Can I get you to verify that the version of OVS that you're seeing this on contains the linked fix? If it is, then we might still need to come up with some kind of solution, just not one that involves sleep().

Hi,
Most likely you received a letter, but I will duplicate it here:
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-dev/2022-November/399720.html

Hi, Terry. Thanks for you comments.
If you mean python-ovs version, so it is 2.13.5, while ovsdb-server was running 2.17.3. As I see (https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/70f6efa41cf72288c53a9a1f2bfee4f661d8097e) in our version your fix is present.

Hmm, well that is unfortunate. Ultimately, if I understand correctly from previous conversations with ovs devs, OVS is supposed to always send the update messages to clients *before* it sends the transaction response indicating that the transaction succeeded. So if there is a case where on a single server we send a create and that row does not exist in our in-memory db when we have a txn status of SUCCESS, then there is a bug.

It's entirely possible that I'm remembering that conversation incorrectly, so I'll try to verify that. But I'm almost completely sure that this is something we need to fix at the ovs or python-ovs level.

I've never tried mixing python-ovs of an older version with a newer ovsdb-server either. Also python-ovs 2.17.1+ is nice because it supports update3/monitor_cond_since. Just sayin'. ;)
OK, we will try to prepare a script tomorrow with which you can reproduce this problem.

We can't introduce a sleep in the transaction processing pipeline, it will block even things like handling echo requests from the ovsdb-server.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message: So we want it to fail on "", too?

I wonder if we really want to raise here.  utils.get_host_nqn() may return an empty string (when priv_nvme.create_hostnqn() swallows an Exception), which isn't much more useful than None.  On the other hand, that could be an argument for also checking here for '' and raising.  I think we need to check with Gorka (see line 414 below, which makes me think a None hostnqn shouldn't be fatal, but I don't understand this part of the code well enough, he may be talking about something else there).

I agree with Gorka that this is a reasonable patch. 
The message should be something like "NVMe: hostnqn not found". Slightly different to Sofia's suggestion as this is a genetic NVMe message, not NVMeOF which is slightly different. The semantics of this protocol are very complex and confusing so we need to be sematically correct.

I believe that if host_nqn is not returned by get_host_nqn NVMe connections will not work, so this patch seems right to me.  In some cases this will fail on the Cinder driver side if they do host nqn based ACLs.

The hostnqn from L414-415 is referring to a different, but related, one. It's the one in sysfs for a specific connection, whereas this on is the "global default" one that will be used if one is not forced by the Cinder driver.

Adding context for other reviewers.

We recently hit bug[0] in the container build job, Patch[1] brought the issue to notice as we changed that playbook to use the ansible controller interpreter rather than discovering it.

To fix the issue we merged patches [2] and [3] that add `buildcontainers_venv: false` and use system packages(rpm content) instead of using venv. Moving away from venv bring another issue into notice that depends-on with container-build job doesn't work(as currently we don't include `build-test-package` role in container-build job, more details in [4]) 

With this patch of venv using --site-packages, we can go back to `buildcontainers_venv: true` if we want to, Rabi already tested that(details in [5]).


[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1996874
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/864647/3/tripleoclient/v2/tripleo_container_image.py
[2] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/config/+/46139
[3] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/rdo-jobs/+/46141
[4] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1997539/
[5] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1997539/comments/2

Just want to clarify that irrespective of if we go back to `buildcontainers_venv: true` or not for container-build, this patch is the right thing to do to fix the workflow. We will not need the revert of this patch even if we add build-test-packages support in the container and image build job.

manila/share/drivers/infinidat/infinibox.message: Don't you need to look at the value ohf nfinidat_snapdir_visible too?

Hello Goutham,

Thank you very much for the review!

Yes of course! But please note - for some historical reason, the `snapdir_accessible` is a property for the Infinidat filesystem.
And `snapdir_visible` is a property for the Infinidat share.
So we checks the `snapdir_accessible` value in the `ensure_share` function,
and checks the `snapdir_visible` value in the `_ensure_filesystem_export` function: 
```
+        expected = self.configuration.infinidat_snapdir_visible
+        if actual is not expected:
+            LOG.debug('Update snapdir_visible for %s: %s -> %s',
+                      infinidat_filesystem.name, actual, expected)
+            infinidat_export.update_snapdir_visible(expected)
+        return self._make_export_locations(infinidat_export)
```

Thank you!

Hello Goutham,

Thank you very much for the review and detailed explanations!
I've added this method in patch set #3. Please review.

Thank you!

This fix wouldn't help previously created snapshots, and clones of snapshots... is there a suggestion for a workaround? 

We do have an "ensure_share" and "ensure_shares" mechanism where, during driver startup, the driver could reconcile some things on shares... that's one option to make changes to existing resources automatically.

Hello Goutham,

Thank you very much for the review and provided information!

Yes, we can use the "migration_ignore_files" configuration option,
but we would like to support host assistant migration "out of the box".

And the .snapshot directory has some other side effects, so I think the best option is to make that directory accessible but hidden by default, but provide the option to change that behaviour (with infinidat_snapdir_accessible and infinidat_snapdir_visible options).

Fixed in patch set #2: I've added code to the ensure_share/ensure_shares to fix all previously created shares.

The reason for the failure is because "tempest_roles" parameter is set to "member" in tempest.conf
It means that member role is assigned to reader user i.e. reader behaves like a member user.

If you set "tempest_roles" to "reader" it'll work, but you don't really need to use this parameter, the roles are assigned within the tests.

You don't need this anymore. Can you drop it? This option is needed because the 'get_item_properties' function does so normalization of the column names provided via column. This allows us to do e.g.

    utils.get_item_properties(s, ['Name', 'Updated At'])

where 'Name' and 'Updated At' are the human readable versions of the field names. The 'get_item_properties' function will automatically convert these to 'name' and 'updated_at'. However, some clients (like novaclient here) return fields in camelCase rather than snake_case, and we need to avoid normalizing the camelCase field names (i.e. we should actually retrieve the 'serverId' field, rather than converting this to 'server_id'). Since openstacksdk does the normalization for us, we shouldn't need this.

I think the bug is really in this block. The -c option isn't adding additional columns, it should override the default list of columns. So columns and column_headers should be reset to empty here.

But I also must admit that I don't completely understand how this is currently working. Like when I do "server list -c ID", only the ID column is being output, but that doesn't match what is being done in this code.
We can't override columns here, otherwise it would lose other columns that are added before in the code.

Rather than doing what you're doing below, you could avoid adding certain columns if the user already requested '--long'. Something like this:

  if c in ('Project ID', 'project_id'):
      ...
  ... # check for all the columns that aren't emitted with '--long' first

  # some of these options are already emitted when passing --long,
  # so if the user requested them again simply ignore the request
  if parsed_args.long:
      continue

  if c in ("Task State", "task_state"):
      ...
  ...  # check for all the columns that would be emitted with '--long' after
  ...  # we checked for '--long' itself and determined it wasn't
  ...  # present

Hopefully that makes sense?

This is misleading. It's already a tuple before start this. I expect you meant to say "covert to an ordered dict and then back to a tuple to remove duplicates", but you could just say "remove duplicates" and leave it to the user to figure out how it's working.

My main question is why this doesn't work:
controller_ssh_client = topology.list_openstack_nodes(
    group='controller')[0].ssh_client
output = sh.execute(amphora_command,
                    ssh_client=controller_ssh_client).stdout
                    
I think it is because of the ssh keys that are needed to connect to the amphora VM, right?
It looks a bit strange to ssh undercloud in order to ssh the controller in order to ssh the amphora. But maybe there is no other way to apply the proper ssh keys.
Thanks for the review, Edu!

We need to use the undercloud ssh key both for when we ssh the controller & amphora.

But there is no access to the amphora directly from the undercloud. Only the controller has it.

So either way we have to ssh the controller in order to ssh the amphora.

I guess that we can also use the controller ssh client and copy the undercloud ssh key to the controller, and then make another ssh client - an amphora one, which will use the undercloud ssh key, from the controller. But I am not sure how the current ssh modules will behave with such a deep nested ssh sessions. I think that it will be simpler to use the current nested ssh command, instead of copying the key and creating 2 ssh clients which might not work (who knows...)

Here is the "official way" to ssh the amphora for OSP17
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/17.0/html/using_octavia_for_load_balancing-as-a-service/troubleshoot-maintain-lb-service_rhosp-lbaas#use-ssh-connect-lb-instances_troubleshoot-maintain-lb-service

Anyway, it is a very specific case for those amphora fault tests. Maybe if we see that we need to run nested ssh connections in many tests, we could think of another implementation.



Another way is to create a FIP to the amphora's lb_network_ip like we did before, as it probably implements the same, but that is what I am trying to change - it is a lot of unnecessary effort to maintain the amphora FIPs for every failover.

Omer, let me take a look at the document you provided and think a little about the ssh clients.
If I don't find any better solution, this patch LGTM
Thanks Edu

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/optim.message: Do you know what was taking the interface(s) time to restart?  If it's something like duplicate address detection I would assume the same sort of time would be taken before failing, ignoring the error and continuing to the next interface
Ok.  It looks to me from the source that if there are ifup errors, we would not lose any logging, but just continue on to the next interface.

In general I'm not really a fan of ignoring errors which could be masking an underlying issue.  I would have thought the ignore-errors was causing the speed up rather than placing the commands on the same line.  Did you explore whether the ssh timeout could be increased?  Were you able to measure at all how long in the worst case this was taking?

It was taking 60+ seconds for SSH to become available.  "--ignore-errors" is used to allow for variations that could not be produced during testing.

Also, timeout no longer occurs because the interface SSH is using is no longer taken down.  Will update comments for that.

The timeout could have be eliminated by using async in the wrapper playbook but that was an unwanted change.
Not enough time to test in depth, but putting ifdown/ifup into a single command fixed slowness.  --ignore-errors did not effect speed.

This is unrelated to this patch, but in my understanding, the second arg of ``sum`` is ``start`` [1].
Why do you use ``[]`` for the second arg?

[1] https://docs.python.org//3/library/functions.html?highlight=sum

This statement expands the list of lists.
'''
>>> sum([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]],[])
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
'''
This second parameter is initial value of the sum. At first [] + [1,2,3] = [1,2,3] is computed and second, [1,2,3] + [4,5,6] = [1,2,3,4,5,6] is done. If using default value for second parameter, then 0 + [1,2,3] = error.

Please note that I said it's unrelated, but I think this part is related to the condition to raise an error caught by the removed test case [1].

Yes, this proposed change works and I don't want to bypass the proxy server to establish a direct connection to a running QEMU instance. For more technical details, please look at my reply to your comment.

> Mayhaps metadata on flavours could carry the necessary details then?

I'm also not convinced by the flavor/metadata idea for an more generic solution in the future. Flavors/metadata are mainly used to prescribe the resources provided to a virtual machine. In other words: The world within a VM is prescribed in more detail. For the SPICE compression settings, an operator requires more knowledge about the outside world (infrastructure). Therefore, it's more secure that only operators have the possibility to configure SPICE compression settings rather than users. A normal user has never the proper insight to configure the settings correctly, unless presets and limits are specified.

You're right, thanks for pointing out that the permission model would perfectly fit for such an idea. In my perspective regarding the software architecture of OpenStack, I focused more on the intention of flavors/metadata. Your idea can be solved technically without any problem, but such a solution might misuse the official intention of flavors/metadata.

I totally agree with Sean's presented use cases. Such use cases are my driving force for this proposed spec. The operator can decide how to configure a desktop (console) transport via SPICE. This is useful if different use cases have to be addressed. For example, if you only want to access some graphical instances for visualization of computation results locally, it is beneficial to explicitly disable all SPICE compression settings to keep latency as low as possible within a local (wired) network to improve the image quality and the quality of experience (QoE).

As Radosław already said, I took the names for the SPICE compression settings from libvirt/QEMU, as that is the only source of reference. But this does not mean that SPICE is a libvirt/QEMU feature. SPICE is a standalone component implemented in QEMU and configurable by Libvirt. E.g. VMware could implement SPICE, too. (But I don't think that will happen one day.) Therefore, we can also rename the options in the SPICE configuration group if the proposed ones are not that good.

I also like Sean's idea which addresses a generic extension of the console API to set various settings for each console of an instance. However, such a dynamic solution involves a lot of changes and problems, especially when I think of regions, cells, and live migration.

specs/zed/approved/spice-compression-sup.message: I'll ask the same question here that I asked on the code review. Rather than exposing these knobs and dials and asking the user to do the research to determine which option to set, could we (nova) be opinionated and choose one that we enable by default? > Rather than exposing these knobs and dials and asking the user to do the research to determine which option to set, could we (nova) be opinionated and choose one that we enable by default?

Here, I want to point out the following libvirt/QEMU fallacy: Many people think that if there is no SPICE compression setting in a libvirt config, then compression is completely turned off. However, this is not correct because libvirt only configures the specified compression settings for QEMU in such a case, which means that all other settings are set to QEMU's defaults (see https://github.com/qemu/qemu/blob/0ebf76aae58324b8f7bf6af798696687f5f4c2a9/ui/spice-core.c#L774). Long story short: I proposed the default compression settings from libvirt/QEMU.

> does this work via the nova spciec proxy in teh web view.

Yes, this approach works with the spice-html5 viewer. I've tested it a few months ago. Currently, the spice-html5 viewer does not support the LZ4 compression (see open task at https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/spice/spice-html5/-/blob/56ddb3005e39a9e76670fec9676e667d44167bf3/TODO). But this fact does not limit the proposed change since LZ4 support is not enabled by default in the spice-server (see https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/spice/spice/-/blob/4a1e9a03f45770e29770b2eea3d996eb2972599c/meson.build#L152) and more important, it is not compiled by default into QEMU (see https://github.com/qemu/qemu/blob/8e3d85d36b77f11ad7bded3a2d48c1f0cc334f82/ui/spice-core.c#L333) nor supported by libvirt at all (see https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/b8e94066f078977906effad7e54e9320f5d1fd98/src/conf/domain_conf.h#L1836).


> nova does not support user bypassing teh proxy and direclty connecting to the spice endpoint on the qemu isntance.

I'm aware of that. A direct bypass of a proxy (access gateway) should never be allowed, otherwise the security can be leveraged and internal functionality can no longer be guaranteed (e.g. transparent access to a running instance that is live migrated if we do not consider the built-in SPICE migration support).


> so if we configure spice compruesseion i guess websockify with convert the spcie tcp stream (which will now have compresss data) into a websocket connection which will be rendered using javascript and html 5 in your browaser corect.

You're right. That happens behind the scenes. Since the data is not only compressed up to the proxy, but up to the client browser (e.g. home), the transport of desktop content should be improved, especially if there is a bottleneck (low bandwidth network) between the client and the cloud.


> this will not enabel endusers to connect form there home with a spice client like virt-viewer directly.

That's correct.

FYI: We are planning an extended SPICE proxy server (access gateway) in the context of a VDI extension for OpenStack, so that the desktop of a running instance can also be transparently accessed by native clients (e.g. remote-viewer/virt-viewer). Such a plan is part of the major goal that we presented in a paper (see https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-99191-3_12) and is already being discussed in the community (see https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-July/029381.html). A key challenge here will be to unite two different cloud infrastructure models, namely cloud computing and VDI. The code base of OpenStack itself should only be adapted as little as possible, so that a base installation of OpenStack does not depend on any VDI logic/features to preserve the intended functionality for pure cloud computing. Then, the VDI functionality (from the code point of view) is really just an extension for OpenStack (where additional service(s) and APIs are implemented which reuse APIs from available components). But that's another story and will lead to further discussions/blueprints/specs.
Sean just highlighted this to me. These look like pretty sane defaults. What's off with them that means this is not the case? Does 'auto' not do what you'd think it does?

In older nova configurations (before this change) we have no possibility to set the SPICE compression options. The defaults of QEMU are used there, since no compression settings are explicitly configured by libvirt. But with the proposed spec, SPICE compression settings can be set explicitly, which can change the behavior. In the default case (no SPICE compression options specified in a Nova configuration), we should use the same defaults as before the proposed change (implicit configuration through libvirt/QEMU) to preserve the same SPICE behavior.

OK, after a few double-checks, I eventually found that we *don't* have an API contract for how we name our multi-create instances.
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=create-multiple-servers-detail#create-multiple-servers

Accordingly, the naming change isn't a behavioural change we're officially needing to do by a microversion.

For *that* specific reason, I now consider the hostname change as an implementation detail (even if this hurts 99% of users that do multi-create) and I can explain that if they feel they're impacted, that's unfortunate but they can later parse the hostname by a server show.

That said, other cores may share the same concern. I hereby propose then to merge this spec as it is, ask to have the multicreate naming change (suffix to prefix) be done in a specific patch in the series (ideally the last) and let people review that during the implementation phase.
If, during those reviews, we may arrive to another solution (like enforcing a third solution, which could be to stick with the suffix on an hostname-like part of the FQDN (guessed magically by Nova)), then we could later modify this spec to make it consistent with the reality.

Either way, I think this is time for us to make a contract on the multicreate naming, which should be done by this API microversion we're going to write for supporting FQDNs.

In Cinder, we introduced the concept of generalized resource filters[1] from microversion 3.33[2] (and extended features in 3.34) instead of defining filters separately for each resource GET operation. Basically, we make the filters admin 
configurable with the resource_filters.json file[3] where the backup filters are defaulted to name, status and volume_id as you have mentioned. Operators can extend these filters to any field that the DB can query in the backup table[4].

If you also follow the example in the generalized filters doc[1], you will see "size" as a valid field for list backups.

list backup*	id, name, status, container, availability_zone, description, volume_id, is_incremental, size, host, parent_id

NOTE: All this will only work if you specify MV>=3.33.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/queens/admin/generalized_filters.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/openstack/api_version_request.py#L86-L90
[3] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/etc/cinder/resource_filters.json#L6
[4] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L1002-L1024

So this means the only way to create a shard is to add node['shard_key']. What do we do if a shard gets created (e.g. baremetal node update set shard_key=banana) and then later remove that shard_key from all nodes (e.g. baremetal node update set shard_key=null or similar). 

Should we keep:
Name: Banana
Count: 0
Last-Updated: $TIME

in the DB, or should that row be deleted? 

IMO we should consider deleting the row to prevent this table growing unbounded; but I also feel like is an extreme edge case; so YAGNI?

I reviewed this initially with the understanding that we would have a db table that included all the shard values. But we don't. So some of the discussion above is moot. The only way to create a shard value, is to actually set it in one or more ironic nodes. and that shard value disappears if no ironic node refers to it.

Without a definitive list of shard keys, this could lead to some problems, esp if humans modify/set the value. Even with some automated process, how would the automation know to add a new shard value vs using an existing shard value for a new ironic node? Might be worth adding something about what is outside the scope of this spec. Eg, are we trying to get the plumbing (support for a new 'shard' field in an ironic node) done. And defer any automated way of assigning shard values to ironic nodes to later/different spec?

i'm still reading but I feel like Jay and Julia have some knowledge that hasn't been written down yet in this spec. So they may want to populate the shard table with 10 shard keys, and then let whatever algorithm (I thought it was mentioned in this spec) randomly assign shard values when an ironic node is created... OR if not using the algorithm, that admin can let the humans that manually enter ironic nodes, to use shard-key-X because (I know, you don't want to hear this) they also decided that each shard key would mean more than a random thing...

specs/approved/shard-key.rst.message:
> > This can be helped with the new DR and operating model Nova is discussing. They envision a deployment with 10000 nodes.
> 
> What is DR?

Disaster Recovery model.

Basically they want to get rid of the hash ring in the nova-compute code, so operators, for ensured uptime will need to handle failover/handling themselves to match the CONF.host value.
> 
> > 
> > They envision more an operating model of no more than 500 "instances" assigned to a nova compute, generally ~250 nodes. This would translate to 40 shards needing to be configured, which means 40 distinct nova-compute processes could be executed to track the nodes and update status.
> 
> We have 10k nodes & 25 nova-computes ... we can ofc add more resources and ~double them as well to reduce the discovery time (as they envision), but the *real* problem is the serial nature of the resource tracker and the way it stores data for the nodes (as pointed out many times). Are there plans to change this?

There are no plans to change this. 😭 Think of this as the compromise none of us wanted.

> 
> Moving to shard keys will not make any difference here, will it?
> 
> 

For your deployment, not really. You'll just be able to disjoint conductor groups if you choose to migrate.

> > 
> > > 
> > > b) moving nodes between conductor groups (instantiated or not) creates havoc.
> > > 
> > > Does the proposed sharding help with any of these or pave the way to a solution?
> > 
> > Sort of yes. We'll have a tool, but it will require the source nova-compute process to be offline. The new logic will also have some guarding logic to *not* delete the compute node anymore if it thinks it has disappeared. Since we can ask ironic "is this still at thing?" and respond accordingly.

I think you read it backwards.

Lets talk about a 10k node cluster; and say that nova-computes can handle ~1k nodes per machine and conductors can handle ~2.5k nodes per machine. These are numbers that are made up, and only exist to demonstrate my understanding that a single conductor can (generally, depending on how quickly you cycle them) handle 2x+ the nodes a nova-compute can.

--example--

---with conductor groups---

In a world where I use conductor groups to scale:
1k nodes (max a nova-compute can handle) in group1, group1 needs at least 2 conductors for HA so you have two conductors; you'd also need 2 nova-computes for HA, so you'd end up with 40 total management services after getting to group 10 (each group needs 2x conductor, 2x compute)

---with shard key instead---

In a world where I use shard_keys to scale, separate from conductor group (assuming an install where conductor groups are generally not desired or needed):
1k nodes in shard1 (2 nova-computes)
...to shard10, giving me a total of 20 nova-compute services

However; because now I can take the load of all 10k nodes and put them into a single conductor group, I can get away with only needing 5 or 6 conductor services running (4*2.5k + 1 or 2 extra for HA).

--end example--


These scaling numbers are somewhat made up, but demonstrate the fact that nova-compute and ironic-conductors scale differently: generally speaking; you can handle a large number of managed nodes on a single ironic-conductor for use cases where nodes are not redeployed frequently. That lack of churn barely even impacts how well nova-compute can scale, which is generally limited by how quickly a nova-compute can download and access all nodes it's managing.

author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

specs/approved/shard-key.rst.message:
Well, not download, but cycle and update resource tracker/placement.

I think Jay does demonstrate it really quite well. The other aspect is Nova wants to nuke the hash ring code out of Nova as it is viewed as the root of all user experience nightmares with ironic. To be truthful, it combined with our state changes make this difficult in the nova model where things are always static and in the nova spec which will use the shard keys, it at least should have the stability moving forward when lined up with the shard keys.

The plus side of all of this, the conductor_group query capability won't disappear from nova. And a command will get introduced to fix the records in nova...

Conductor groups require you to separate your conductor capacity. Conductors scale MUCH higher than nova-compute instances. These are two separate scaling curves, and beyond any sort of API-cleanliness argument (reusing conductor groups is ugly from this perspective IMO), we should not force users at scale to overprovision and maintain separate groups of conductors.

I am extremely opposed to tying the maximum size of a conductor cluster to the maximum amount of nodes that a nova-compute can handle.

I run a deployment which is *very* close to the example. The issue is not to find a few VMs to run the Ironic control plan for 10k nodes (and I guess it is not for anyone at this scale). The scaling problems I have are:

a) it takes the combined system Nova+Ironic too long to find a node when it moves to available (b/c of the resource tracker), and

b) moving nodes between conductor groups (instantiated or not) creates havoc.

Does the proposed sharding help with any of these or pave the way to a solution?

author.name: Julia Kreger

specs/approved/shard-key.rst.message:
It is a bit of both.

Ironic returns the list relatively quickly. Even faster now.

Something like 70% of the time CERN calculated with the performance modeling they did was spent looping through the nova compute service's internals as it sequentially iterates through the entire list it gets, and performs actions from there synchronizing data and tracking resources.

So, the idea is that they need to be able to split/delineate the work into smaller chunks. Some services, like networking-baremetal which does the exact same thing, but with port data.

In nova's case, they want a human to make an explicit decision and lock it into place. They also want to get rid of the buggy HA model in that they always delete/recreate things as opposed to update the host field, which creates a lot of database churn leading to a number of issues which have no fix at present which nova will approve.

In the networking-baremetal, we can allow the service to self delineate fairly easily. Nova will require configuration to leverage this, but it should be easier, and less risk prone/problematic.

Ah. I think this is very useful information. It clarifies what "polling" entails, cuz it isn't just polling, it is what the caller/consumer (nova) does with the information which slows down nova, not ironic. Worth adding this to the problem description!

author.name: Julia Kreger

specs/approved/shard-key.rst.message:
Normally an index is the (primary_key, indexed_field).

A compound index is (primary_key, field_1_index, field_2_index)

Which is much more performant in larger databases if you do "give me all the nodes with field1="foo", field2="foo". A compound index would be used first, instead of a partial index hit, or possibly even a database table scan where the DB engine walks the columns looking for matching values.
Ack

So.. the 'compound index' is on the ironic side and this basically says that we may end up creating one or more compound indexes in ironic to make certain db queries more performant. Which could be follow up work ;)

specs/zed/approved/ironic-fix-management.message:
tl;dr

I think we should drop supporting multiple nova-compute hosts managing a single ironic conductor partition.

We should instead tell users to shard into conductor groups of around 1k nodes, with one nova-compute for each conductor group, using the already supported partition key.

To help with availability, the deployment tooling can use pacemaker, or whatever, to just run one of them on one of your nodes, with CONF.host = <conductor_group_name>. The only real cost of moving is the startup time, which used to be horrendous, but has got better.

I know this is written from the perspective of ironic as normal and nova as weird, but I think it's a little unfair. Nova is not overly static in this regard, it just looks like that when you decouple the lifecycle of the things being managed from the thing doing the management. nova-compute is intended to run with the instances it manages, and if the host those are all on dies or needs to be recycled, the workloads and the manager of those workloads have their fate intertwined. Driving an external service from nova-compute where the fates are necessarily *not* closely linked is not a failure in the design or implementation of Nova, it's just using the tool for something other than intended.

Right, so I'm confused about what is being asserted in the spec here. Is Julia asserting that we are deleting ComputeNode objects when we shouldn't be? Or asserting that we *should* be but *aren't*? The referenced bug doesn't really tell me much.

Yeah, there are only two ways a ComputeNode objects (and corresponding database row) can be deleted in nova.

1. If the DELETE /os-services/{service_id} API is called by a user (admin). This means the nova-compute Service object will be deleted [1] and the matching ComputeNode object will be deleted [2]. Note that in this case, the ComputeNode does not map to an ironic node -- it is the ComputeNode representing the nova-compute service being deleted.

2. If an ironic node is deleted. Nova will detect that its list of ComputeNode objects matching the ironic node list has a mismatch and the ironic driver will delete the ComputeNode that has no ironic node anymore and say, "Deleting orphan compute node".

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/61b161eeaaed9e228b735f7c6793e7fc5bf1a830/nova/api/openstack/compute/services.py#L340
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/61b161eeaaed9e228b735f7c6793e7fc5bf1a830/nova/db/main/api.py#L390

+1 for tweaking conf.host.

I would recommend using the ironic conductor group name, i.e. the partition key.

I think the problem there is that the controller replacement should be making sure that the new controller has the same hostname as the one being replaced. That's not normally a problem, but if you're running nova-compute on your controllers for ironic, then the hostname has to be the same. The fact and reason that it's not happening in this case is really tripleo-specific and not necessarily a nova problem, it's just a rule that needs to be respected.

One way to solve that generically would be to just advise people as  a best-practice to set their CONF.hostname for ironic computes to some token (i.e. "ironic-1", "ironic-3", etc). That way if you need to re-deploy an ironic compute somewhere else, the identity (and thus the instances for which it is responsible) are restored. I would say "database surgery" is not the proper solution to that problem either.

we do not expect the service to compute node mapping to be a product of an in memory dynimc hash ring implmeation. we expect the compute service to only change as a result of an operator deploying a new serice or calling the api.

So we have two sources of truth, i) nova DB, ii) hashring in ironic-driver. During rebalance ii) is changed but i) is not. So the system becomes inconsistent.

So either:
a) ii) should not change in a rebalance
Or 
b) i) also needs to change during a rebalance to match with ii)

Probably a) is not possible without as the rebalance is a must if we lost a nova-compute service.

So we need to make b) work. To do that we need to move the instances and compute node objects to a different nova-compute service:

* As Sean noted above the only way to move an instance away from a dead nova-compute service is to evacuate it. But evacuate also means moving the instance to a different hypervisor / compute node. In case of ironic rebalance only the nova-compute service needs to be change but not the compute node.

* Today there is no way in nova to move a compute node to a different nova-compute service.

the operation started when it was up.

there are at least two related concerns around aggregates and cells.

in nova's api db comptue services and trastiivly all comptue comptute nodes 
managed by that compute service are mapped to a cell
an instance is also mapped to a cell based on the compute node they are assigned to.

the hash ring may not move compute nodes or instances between nova cells.
currently, the driver does not know what cell it is in nor does the hash ring.

if the driver/hash ring naively rebalances the compute nodes without considering the cell boundaries then the node will still be unmanageable as the request will be sent to the wrong message bus.


in a more user-facing concern, all compute services and hosts beneath them are mapped to an Availability Zone.

Availability zones are also defined as metadata on host aggregates in the API DB, not the cell DB.

compute services are not allowed to upcall to the API DB and individual compute service/driver do not know what AZ they may or may not be part of.

host aggregates are mapped to compute services.
a compute service may have many host aggregates associated with it for things like the tenant isolation filter or many other scheduling reasons.

since the hash-ring/driver knows nothing about the relationship between the compute service and the aggregates it's a member of it cannot safely rebalance as it might move the compute to a different az or host aggregate that would violate the

tenant isolation or other requirements that were first enforced when scheduling.

Right, there's a whole host of "what goes where" information that is maintained at the top level and enforced by scheduling and/or the APIs. That stuff may also include some things like disabled cells and other scheduling policy, in addition to the things Sean noted here.

Computes are already too complicated for what they should be doing, and pushing a top-level view of the whole deployment's architecture and isolation policy to them is not reasonable (nor feasible because of cell and api-db separations). This is one of my primary concerns around the computes either unilaterally adopting things they think they need to manage, or attempting to collude to make that decision, not knowing if there's another cell of computes that might be having a parallel election.

I totally get it. I don't like it either, but also I don't see other way to trigger a move in a way that the actual update can be triggered from the compute but the API level constraints are also enforced.

> 
> I think we'd also have to disallow that based on virt type from the API so as not to let people be arbitrarily re-assigning their libvirt compute nodes to other services.
> 

Yep. I assume we have a lot of API requests that is not supported for ironic, now there will be one that is only supported for ironic virt driver.

> > So I think we need to add a new POST /os-hypervisors/<compute-node-uuid> API that allows changing the ["service"]["host"] field of the hypervisor (i.e. compute node) to trigger the move. Then such action can be handled by the nova-api or nova-superconductor service on the API level to check preconditions (e.g. aggregates, cells, AZs constraints). Then forward the request to the nova cell conductor in the cell where the move happens (as it cannot happen between cells). Then the nova-conductor in the cell can do the DB update under a lock, to prevent race conditions between competing nova-compute services claiming ownership over the same compute node.
> 
> What lock? The two computes involved won't be collaborating on a lock while running their resource tracker loops, and the conductor can't really lock anything about the compute nodes from other conductors. It can make an atomic reassignment of the host in the DB, but that's about it. Is that what you mean?
> 

Good point. We can only do atomic reassignment, not a real lock. 

> If so, I still think there's a weird "eventual consistency" situation that happens when you do that in the middle of resource manager updates by either of the two related computes.
> 

Can we reject updates that are coming from a different nova-compute service to a compute node already assigned to another nova-compute? It would not totally remove the eventual consistency situation but shrink the window.  

> > I know that this means a lot more work as it needs a new REST API and RPC between the API and the Cell layer. Also this might cause scaling issues after a cold start when a lot of moves needed.
> 
> There's a lot involved here, I think, especially if you assume this API would be called en masse after some event to reassign a bunch of things. You'd have many conductors reassigning compute node pairs between compute hosts in parallel. You'd certainly have to disable any of the hash ring stuff during that time so that computes aren't spewing results or fighting you. Or are you expecting to remove the hash ring entirely in this scenario?

I don't think we can remove the hashring, as that is the source of the actual reassignment. That has the logic to assign a compute node to different compute service. If we remove the ring then there won't be any reassignment ever. I think if we want to avoid overload then we should limit the number of nova-compute services brought up at a given time. This will not decrease the total amount of reassignment probably, but it will spread them over time.

> > there is not management api for comptue service to compute node operations today in nova.
> 
> I think this is the missing piece. What we would need is way to ask nova to move a compute node to another nova-compute service (and move the instances on that compute node along).

So you want to add an API operation that is effectively a "special ironic thing"? I'm not sure I can get behind that ... :)

I think we'd also have to disallow that based on virt type from the API so as not to let people be arbitrarily re-assigning their libvirt compute nodes to other services.

> So I think we need to add a new POST /os-hypervisors/<compute-node-uuid> API that allows changing the ["service"]["host"] field of the hypervisor (i.e. compute node) to trigger the move. Then such action can be handled by the nova-api or nova-superconductor service on the API level to check preconditions (e.g. aggregates, cells, AZs constraints). Then forward the request to the nova cell conductor in the cell where the move happens (as it cannot happen between cells). Then the nova-conductor in the cell can do the DB update under a lock, to prevent race conditions between competing nova-compute services claiming ownership over the same compute node.

What lock? The two computes involved won't be collaborating on a lock while running their resource tracker loops, and the conductor can't really lock anything about the compute nodes from other conductors. It can make an atomic reassignment of the host in the DB, but that's about it. Is that what you mean?

If so, I still think there's a weird "eventual consistency" situation that happens when you do that in the middle of resource manager updates by either of the two related computes.

> I know that this means a lot more work as it needs a new REST API and RPC between the API and the Cell layer. Also this might cause scaling issues after a cold start when a lot of moves needed.

There's a lot involved here, I think, especially if you assume this API would be called en masse after some event to reassign a bunch of things. You'd have many conductors reassigning compute node pairs between compute hosts in parallel. You'd certainly have to disable any of the hash ring stuff during that time so that computes aren't spewing results or fighting you. Or are you expecting to remove the hash ring entirely in this scenario?

> > Can we reject updates that are coming from a different nova-compute service to a compute node already assigned to another nova-compute? It would not totally remove the eventual consistency situation but shrink the window.
> 
> Reject from where? In conductor or placement? Placement doesn't know about the assignment (right?) and conductor would have to effectively look up the assignment before each write or whatever. Seems sketchy to me...

I thought about rejecting it from the conductor perspective. But you have a point that the compute also updates Placement not just the conductor.

> 
> > I don't think we can remove the hashring, as that is the source of the actual reassignment. That has the logic to assign a compute node to different compute service. If we remove the ring then there won't be any reassignment ever. I think if we want to avoid overload then we should limit the number of nova-compute services brought up at a given time. This will not decrease the total amount of reassignment probably, but it will spread them over time.
> 
> What I meant was remove the management of the hash ring from the computes, in terms of responsibility. By "remove the hash ring" I meant an arrangement where computes just manage nodes that are assigned to their service and something else decides to change those assignments. Still concerned about who does that and how much ironic information they need to have.

Ahh I see now. Yes, that could move the problem of reassignment to a place where it is easier to implement. I.e. we we move the hashring to the nova API layer (I know we don't want to as that would be ironic specific code) then the reassignment code will have the information about cells without any upcalls.

> Yep. I assume we have a lot of API requests that is not supported for ironic, now there will be one that is only supported for ironic virt driver.

Yeah, but an array of features that are supported by some virt drivers but not all is different than a completely bespoke thing that will only ever be supported by one. When we're looking to plumb things through, even if we're maybe only ever going to support it for one, I think it's important to look at what other drivers might need if they wanted to be able to support the feature in the future. 

> Can we reject updates that are coming from a different nova-compute service to a compute node already assigned to another nova-compute? It would not totally remove the eventual consistency situation but shrink the window.

Reject from where? In conductor or placement? Placement doesn't know about the assignment (right?) and conductor would have to effectively look up the assignment before each write or whatever. Seems sketchy to me...

> I don't think we can remove the hashring, as that is the source of the actual reassignment. That has the logic to assign a compute node to different compute service. If we remove the ring then there won't be any reassignment ever. I think if we want to avoid overload then we should limit the number of nova-compute services brought up at a given time. This will not decrease the total amount of reassignment probably, but it will spread them over time.

What I meant was remove the management of the hash ring from the computes, in terms of responsibility. By "remove the hash ring" I meant an arrangement where computes just manage nodes that are assigned to their service and something else decides to change those assignments. Still concerned about who does that and how much ironic information they need to have.

I know this is all focused on changes to Nova to make it work better for Ironic, but have we considered changes to Ironic to make it more hypervisor-y? If ironic exposed nodes in groups and each compute just managed whatever its assigned group is, then maybe ironic could help by offlining a node, removing it from a group, reassigning, etc. Some combination of nova changes and ironic changes seem like they might be more palatable than just hacking in not-a-hypervisor changes into all layers of nova.

I think this is the missing piece. What we would need is way to ask nova to move a compute node to another nova-compute service (and move the instances on that compute node along). As this potentially depends on nova API level information (host aggregates, AZs, cells) such move operation should be checked on the nova API DB level (nova-api or nova-superconductor level). This also means that the actual move needs to be triggered from above (i.e. from REST API) as from below (i.e nova-compute) we have no way to talk to the API level (as we don't want to add more up-calls). 

(This is probably similar to Option: "Make the nova conductor handle assignments and assign nodes")

So I think we need to add a new POST /os-hypervisors/<compute-node-uuid> API that allows changing the ["service"]["host"] field of the hypervisor (i.e. compute node) to trigger the move. Then such action can be handled by the nova-api or nova-superconductor service on the API level to check preconditions (e.g. aggregates, cells, AZs constraints). Then forward the request to the nova cell conductor in the cell where the move happens (as it cannot happen between cells). Then the nova-conductor in the cell can do the DB update under a lock, to prevent race conditions between competing nova-compute services claiming ownership over the same compute node.

Nova is an abstraction layer, and as such, it is not able to surface every feature and quirk of every underlying technology it wraps. That's a good thing.

I think that expecting any real solution (or even incremental improvement) to this being backportable is pointless. AFAICT, anything discussed so far would have substantial impacts to deployments if the new code wasn't rolled out atomically to all computes during a maintenance window, which rules out backports, IMHO.

Which conductor? The conductors are headless, nameless, anonymous, and have no persistence. They also have no concept of the virt driver being used on the computes. Unless you kicked this off with an API command and let whichever one happens to handle the request do a full reshuffle, you'd need a big lock somewhere and all the conductors would have churning periodics fighting for that lock all the time.

The above does not sound good to me, nor does giving something that is highly virt-dependent to conductor, which has no concept of such things today.

I should probably expand on this but I need to think about how to express this clearly...


tl;dr is as follows.


add a new shard_key option to the ironic compute section of the nova.conf
default this to socket.gethostname()
create one nova compute service record per cell/az pair where ironic is deployed
in each such region set the [DEFAULT]host=ironic_<cell>_<az>
run 1-n nova-compute agent process using the same conf.Host value

each nova-compute agent process started in this way would share the same message queue names and would all be able to respond to RPC request to this compute service endpoint.

this would allow an active/active compute service deployment where its horizontally scaleable by just adding new compute agent processes.

the shared key would be used as an import to the hash ring so that each compute service would only process periodic for the subset of computing that is assigned to them by the hash ring.

this would eliminate the need for rebalance entirely at the nova compute manager level. since we would not need to update the compute node to compute service mapping or the instance.host and comptuenode.host values.

this would mean that comptue-nodes/instance would never be at risk of moving between cells or AZ and violating the schedulign constraits express via aggreate or placement metatata since netierh compute node or instance are "moving"


we are instead leavergin the message bus to supprot multiple producer (api) multipel consumer (compute agent process) model and then internally in the driver sharding the host that specific instance of nova-comptue actully runs periodic tasks for.

there are some open question with this such as how does the hashring know which agents are alive. and how does the resouce traker work in this case.

to fasialte that likely we would need some way for the driver to share state such as via memcace or the message bus or even ironic.


but i think somehting along this direction could work.

I understand the benefits of this, and probably something along the lines of this are what we'll need to do. However, as you note, it's not clear how the computes would decide who would do the RT updates. I also worry that it would cause ironic-specific bits to bleed upwards into the compute manager and resource tracker, and if not, we'd end up with some churn as things flip flop back and forth as computes slowly digest environmental changes.

It would break our current notion of seeing services via the API, as it would look like you have one ironic compute when you have N. Anything we need to do that affects the compute service would need to be a different type of message over RPC in this configuration. For example, enabling/disabling a host (which you would no longer be able to do really anyway) would send the set_host_enabled() RPC call to just one of those computes. Things like get_host_uptime() would report a constantly-changing value as we'd poll a different one each time. Neither of these is perhaps all that important, but either we need to document in the API that things'd be broken for ironic, or work out some way to make them work for ironic at the higher layers.
you woudl need to so some sort of leader election or supprot a raft like protocal to make hat robust but yes.

They all look up the service.id of each (relevant) service and decide they're the leader if self.service.id==min(service_ids). That would keep it stable over time instead of each election potentially being random or time-based.

Either way, this involves some potential breakage if it just happens automatically, right? If we rebalance instances and nodes in realtime, a request that comes in while that is happening may go to the wrong compute service. However, if the point is to purely re-home orphaned instances, then maybe that's less of a problem.

However, it still ends up being ironic-specific and not something the ironic driver can really do periodically in the background today. I'm not sure I like the ironic driver occasionally re-writing things it doesn't really own in the database that would change what is going on in the compute manager that "owns" it. It would need to share the RT lock I would think to avoid doing that in the middle of a RT update.

the issue is the compute agent really does not have all the infor it need to compute teh rebalnce since basically it need to run all the instance though the scudler again to select which host are valid based on the cell and host aggreate constratis.

I'm not a fan of making a problem statement the shortlog of a commit.  It really should be a short summary of the action that the commit is performing.  eg "Enable fm-api service as part of bootstrap"

Then in the body of the commit, describe the problem that is solved. eg. "fm-api service fails to start after the install stage because the files that it needs aren't there yet.  So we disable it during install and enable it during bootstrap."

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: If this commit merges without the one that depends on it, will the load break?

That case should not make the load break because the services were already configured as enabled during the install stage. The opposite case (merging the other commit first) could break it because the service will be disabled during the installation and will not be enabled after.

tripleo_ansible/roles/snapshot_and_rever.message: Previously in this file and also in other roles like backup and restore we are using this style. We use variable tripleo_rolename_XXX inside the code of the role, but we use the XXX as the parameter to set up the configuration by the user.
Maybe we should call it something more intuitive?
But this seems like both tripleo_snapshot_revert_pacemaker_node_remove and pacemaker_node_remove do the same thing?
It is just a parameter to allow the user to decide to make the snapshots of the controllers at the same time or serialized taking them out of pacemaker one by one
I don't think we mean for this to be plural, do we?
The namespace is different here. Are we borrowing this from another place intentionally?
wow this was introduced by error

The way this is written assumes that this is installed on the host and will return a result. What if this is not installed on the host? Does everything break?

We could do something like 'changed_when: false' (because this doesn't change anything) and 'failed_when: false' to prevent this task failing and ensure that we check the return code as part of the below conditionals.

This is to help ensure that this role is usable for Director-based and non-Director-based deployments.
For the moment I think that we can keep the 1st option and skip pacemaker tasks and assume that puppet and pacemaker are there.

Yep I am assuming that it's installed on the nodes but if this modification will help with non-director-based deployments I can implement your suggestion. The only problem I see here is that if puppet is not installed, we won't have the enabled_services information to remove/add the node to the pacemaker cluster. 
Then we will make this feature useless because we can potentially lose information in the controllers since the node is not taken out of pacemaker.
Another option could be not using puppet to check the services, but reading the services that are running in the containers inside the node. What do you think?

That would again be assuming something about the architecture.

I think it's fine to just skip all the pacemaker parts if puppet is not installed, because then clearly it is not running on a TripleO build.

Alternatively we can presume this is a TripleO build and make sure the whole play fails out if this task fails. We can do that by adding 'any_errors_fatal: true' in the 'TripleO Controller Snapshots' play.

It really depends on what you consider the *requirement* for this functionality. If this is TripleO specific, then we assume puppet & pacemaker are there. If this is potentially going to be used more broadly, then we should check and react to what's there defensively.

I think that an extra file: task is needed to ensure that the ownership of the private key file is correct before the openssl_privatekey module runs.

Otherwise if you want to regenerate the certificate only (not the key) there is no way to prevent the key also being regenerated when the ownership/mode remains wrong.

I've dropped part that triggers private key re-generation for now. The thing is that file task will _always_ be changed in some cases, like storing openstack_deploy folder in git system ,since git does not preserve mode of files.

Actually this looks valid for when the file exists and is not yet created:

  file:
    path: path: "{{ ca_dir ~ '/private/' ~ ca.name ~ '.key.pem' }}"
    state: file
    mode: <..>
    owner: <..>
    group: <..>
    
 `state: If file, even with other options (such as mode), the file will be modified if it exists but will NOT be created if it does not exist`
